replies.body: According to Riot the client will have short lores and the website will have long versions of that lore. There were technical issues that delayed the implementation, though.
This. We're also hoping to serialize lore on the website, so that in addition to the 'long bios' we can add new stories as we go without erasing anything.

I'm a bit biased, but I strongly support the Narrative team erring on the side of synergizing with established lore rather than demolishing it.

Let me preface what follows by saying that Narrative's been showing a more serious commitment to community engagement in recent days than it ever has, at least within the scope of my recollection. Thank you. I also thought the new Sion lore was quite good—and, not unimportantly, meshed very well with established lore.

My primary (substantive) concern about Narrative's current direction is that your thesis seems to be: "This old lore sucks. Let's start with a clean slate." This is an energizing, refreshing attitude, but it's also highly problematic in that "these ruins are inhabited." The lore community has been working with and building upon established lore for years. I would urge Narrative not to treat the destruction of old lore as a cost-free move. LoL's lore gains a lot of strength from community involvement.

As for procedural concerns, while I'm heartened to see you reaching out to discuss lore with the community, so far Narrative has only taken a first step. The crucial next step is giving us some idea as to what's getting redone next, so that we can focus our discussion. (Otherwise, we're left simply making a bunch of shot-in-the-dark threads like, "by the way, if you ever redo Kayle, here's what I think should happen.")

As I've written before, I'd like to see Narrative rely less on shock reveals that come out of nowhere. Shock reveals are exciting, but by their nature also preclude meaningful community engagement. Especially when the new content clashes with established lore, I do not think shock reveals are appropriate.

For example, maybe you want to redo Bandle City and erase the Mothership. That is not a good topic for a shock reveal. That is something that warrants prior discussion with the community, early enough that the discussion can have an impact.

In contrast, adding a story or artwork that simply fleshes out more details of Jarvan II saving Xin Zhao from the arena would be fine as a shock reveal, as would be (e.g.) a cinematic showing Ashe and Sejuani brawling in the Freljord.

> My primary (substantive) concern about Narrative's current direction is that your thesis seems to be: "This old lore sucks. Let's start with a clean slate." This is an energizing, refreshing attitude, but it's also highly problematic in that "these ruins are inhabited." The lore community has been working with and building upon established lore for years. I would urge Narrative not to treat the destruction of old lore as a cost-free move. LoL's lore gains a lot of strength from community involvement.

We don't view it as 'destruction,' but as a tweak to fit with new foundational rules for the world. In making those tweaks we're looking at what players have liked and disliked for what reasons and why, and all those factors enter into our discussions. Fan theories? Check. Past reworks? Check. Recent events? Double check. I absolutely agree that it was on us to tell you we'd be moving in this direction sooner, and that we dropped the ball in that regard. We are, I think, doing well to fix that.

> As for procedural concerns, while I'm heartened to see you reaching out to discuss lore with the community, so far Narrative has only taken a first step. The crucial next step is giving us some idea as to what's getting redone next, so that we can focus our discussion. (Otherwise, we're left simply making a bunch of shot-in-the-dark threads like, "by the way, if you ever redo Kayle, here's what I think should happen.")

We have to be careful here, for what I think are extremely valid reasons. Feedback is fine, but a lot of the time we get requests for what is essentially a spreadsheet on who is working on what and why. That's simply not tenable, and even if it was it would be less the kind of surprise you're thinking of and more of a 'woops we just spoiled x y and z.' I'm happy to cultivate discussions on groups of champs that are coming up soon on the docket (the big thread from Friday being a good example), but there's absolutely a balance we need to strike and I hope you'll respect that. In the meantime, I'm happy to talk about changes that are upcoming for assorted champs we haven't gotten to yet.
 
> As I've written before, I'd like to see Narrative rely less on shock reveals that come out of nowhere. Shock reveals are exciting, but by their nature also preclude meaningful community engagement. Especially when the new content clashes with established lore, I do not think shock reveals are appropriate.

Again, have to be careful here. Do we reveal everything and never surprise you at all, or constantly surprise you and have less interaction? That's the tightrope we're walking. I agree that a 'shock reveal' is unpleasant, but remember that our goal isn't simply to turn everything on its head - we want to shock and delight positively, when at all possible.

> For example, maybe you want to redo Bandle City and erase the Mothership. That is not a good topic for a shock reveal. That is something that warrants prior discussion with the community, early enough that the discussion can have an impact.

The entire world is being redefined, and Bandle City is indeed among the reworks. Some of the changes you might not like, others you probably will. I personally (and be aware that I haven't had any input on Bandle city) *hate* the mothership. Someone else might love it. But we're not going to throw out **or** keep anything based on a small handful of opinions - we keep what makes for the most interesting and vibrant stories, while considering what every side has to say. I hope we can be more transparent of that going forward.

> We have to be careful here, for what I think are extremely valid reasons. Feedback is fine, but a lot of the time we get requests for what is essentially a spreadsheet on who is working on what and why. That's simply not tenable, and even if it was it would be less the kind of surprise you're thinking of and more of a 'woops we just spoiled x y and z.' I'm happy to cultivate discussions on groups of champs that are coming up soon on the docket (the big thread from Friday being a good example), but there's absolutely a balance we need to strike and I hope you'll respect that. **In the meantime, I'm happy to talk about changes that are upcoming for assorted champs we haven't gotten to yet.**

I'll be blunt.  The highlighted portion is what worries me.

It's feels as if there are significant numbers of champions already declared "finished" by Narrative and you're just cynically asking for our input on the rest as a peace offering.

For example, there are a group of new bios already coming out for the Shadow Isles, and I'm pretty sure there's one more area mostly finished coming down the pipeline.  That's about 20 champions whose stories have already been declared "done" without community input.

Again, no idea if any of that is true, but there's nothing from Narrative that's saying otherwise.

Thanks for taking the time to respond. And I know it's not just a matter of time—I know that this is a thorny subject, and I appreciate you taking on some additional stress to interact here. This post is one of the more substantial posts I've seen from a Rioter yet on this topic.

> We don't view it as 'destruction,' but as a tweak to fit with new foundational rules for the world. In making those tweaks we're looking at what players have liked and disliked for what reasons and why, and all those factors enter into our discussions. Fan theories? Check. Past reworks? Check. Recent events? Double check.

I think it's great that those sorts of factors are part of your discussion. That said, there's value to letting the community speak for ourselves, rather than just being represented in absentia, which is why I encourage further public discussion, especially when it comes to major changes.

I do think "destruction" is an appropriate term. There is such a thing as creative destruction. For example, the lore community basically waved aside some of the derpier League-related lore and developed some fanon that made Summoners into "radio support" rather than creepy puppetmasters, and the Institute into a beleaguered EU-style body struggling to maintain legitimacy rather than an all-powerful magocracy. However, there's a fundamental difference between new lore that adds onto established lore and new lore that also destroys some established lore. It's a different calculus with different factors coming into play.

>  Feedback is fine, but a lot of the time we get requests for what is essentially a spreadsheet on who is working on what and why.

I don't know about others, but that's certainly not what I'm asking for. I'm thinking more like, "the next big rework will be Ionia." That allows us to focus our attention on Ionia, and allows for a discussion prefaced with, e.g., "We're thinking of redoing the Noxian invasion of Ionia to bring in Demacia as an ally for Ionia. We also want to highlight Zaun's involvement." This prompts interested parties to speak up and get involved.

> I'm happy to cultivate discussions on groups of champs that are coming up soon on the docket (the big thread from Friday being a good example),

That was indeed a good thread, because it defined (at least generally) one set of Champions up for rewrites and gathered community input.

> Again, have to be careful here. Do we reveal everything and never surprise you at all, or constantly surprise you and have less interaction?

I would propose, as a rule of thumb, that shock reveals are less appropriate to the degree that the incoming lore is destructive. Let's say the story is about Lux and Ezreal going off on an adventure together. This works fine as a surprise, because it meshes with prior lore. But if the story retcons Ezreal to be from Ionia instead of Piltover, that would be something that warrants discussion first, even at the cost of some "excitement".

> The entire world is being redefined, and Bandle City is indeed among the reworks. Some of the changes you might not like, others you probably will. I personally (and be aware that I haven't had any input on Bandle city) hate the mothership. Someone else might love it.

Sure. And this is why something like that should be discussed. Rather than merely factoring in what the Narrative team suspects the community's feelings to be, let the community speak for itself. Our opinions might surprise you. We might come up with alternatives you hadn't considered. Our focus might vary from what you'd expect it to be.

> But we're not going to throw out or keep anything based on a small handful of opinions - we keep what makes for the most interesting and vibrant stories, while considering what every side has to say. I hope we can be more transparent of that going forward.

I'm definitely not arguing for a democratic voting process on new lore: merely for us to be given a chance to have our say, early enough that it might make a difference.

> I do think "destruction" is an appropriate term. There is such a thing as creative destruction. [...] However, there's a fundamental difference between new lore that adds onto established lore and new lore that also destroys some established lore. It's a different calculus with different factors coming into play.

IF IT AIN'T BROKE DON'T FIX IT!

Ok. So, what actually is the point of wanting to communicate more with the community when you dont act on anything? I'm really curious. You say you have a broad universe--shattering change in the works. That statement is met with overwhelming negativity....so you do it anyway?

And dont say "this board is a small fraction of the player base". I fully understand that a majority of the people who play this game dont know anything / dont care lore even a little bit, but we do. The people that come here and voice concerns are among your most dedicated lore fans, and you havent acted on a single thing we have said since *Jayce*. 

Whats the point? every time we dont like recent developments in the lore ( Which has been a lot lately) you see it, say its all going to make sense and to trust you. Thats not community interaction, thats showing up and telling us how its going to be. Theres no back and forth there.

> And dont say "this board is a small fraction of the player base". I fully understand that a majority of the people who play this game dont know anything / dont care lore even a little bit, but we do. The people that come here and voice concerns are among your most dedicated lore fans

I would like to highlight this. We are the "minority" of the community, but we are the people relevant to the discussion. The "majority" doesn't, and never will, care about lore; the majority isn't a factor here. It's unfair to say that "the majority of the community doesn't mind these changes" (or somesuch) when that majority will never notice--let alone care about--anything related to story.

> We don't view it as 'destruction,' but as a tweak to fit with new foundational rules for the world. In making those tweaks we're looking at what players have liked and disliked for what reasons and why, and all those factors enter into our discussions. Fan theories? Check. Past reworks? Check. Recent events? Double check. I absolutely agree that it was on us to tell you we'd be moving in this direction sooner, and that we dropped the ball in that regard. We are, I think, doing well to fix that.

Just to make it abundantly clear here: I am a player of your game. I despise your decision to eliminate the elegant and playful story that made me love your game. I want you to revert that decision. I don't want you to continue in the direction you are going, I firmly believe it is a mistake and your attempts to convince me otherwise have only alienated me to you. I am listening to what you are saying and I fervently disagree with you.

Revert your decision and I promise all will be forgiven and we will move on. I am a fan of Riot Games and I love League, but I cannot say enough how much I hate this decision. Really, HATE. I think about it when I am not playing even.

P.S. When you punch someone's favorite thing and then say it is a tweak and that you really dropped the ball on that one, you sound like a liar. You are NOT doing well to fix that.

You are blind. This **is** destruction indeed. Of the **eight** things this Season 4 that made me think "will I continue to play League after this?" **seven** came out from Lore and Narrative (the other one was the forums going Reddit-style and casting posts like this one into the abyss of the late and unupvoted). I can't see you "looking at what players have liked and disliked for what reasons and why" (Do you survey inside the in-game client? The only time I received one in my server was regarding Gragas rework, and it was just a 5 degree scale of approval, without a field for commentaries), and I can't see your internal discussions.

And that's why I'm all-in for this proposition:

#Shock Reveals are for New Champions being launched
#Community Discussion is for Old Champions being relaunched

If you are walking a tighrope is because **you** want it. You shouldn't suprise us with anything regarding **retcons** (and please, stop calling this retcons as "**tweaks**", this is highly offensive to our emotional attachment to our stories).

#After you lauch Lore and Stories they aren't only yours anymore. They are ours too. Destruction of any PUBLIC story is a deal that must be made and accepted with and by the PUBLIC.

And that's why I'll question the rest of my gamer life the destruction of the Institute of War. Can even the IoW remain as an organization like the League of Justice inside Valoran? With all that independent champions striving for saving the world from another devastation like the Rune Wars **the IoW can remain as a trying of a League of Justice made by the champions in your retconed scenario**.

"Again, have to be careful here. Do we reveal everything and never surprise you at all, or constantly surprise you and have less interaction? That's the tightrope we're walking. I agree that a 'shock reveal' is unpleasant, but remember that our goal isn't simply to turn everything on its head - we want to shock and delight positively, when at all possible."

Well, up until now, the Lore team has consistently gone with "constantly surprise you and have less interaction" and you have seen how that worked out.  Errors and mistakes are UNAVOIDABLE; you have to simply accept that as part of human nature.  Better now to err on the side of too much communication with us.  Look at the bright side.  There are a ton of people who don't bother with this forum, and they would still be utterly surprised by anything you put out.  But if you err on the side of shock reveal again, you will lose the credibility you've worked so hard to build here.  

You keep saying you need to be careful.  I agree; you need to be careful about shattering the last attempt you'll get with a lot of us.  For now, these conversations are still just hypothetical.  You're engaging with us, and that's nice, but we won't know how serious you are until the first new lore comes out that involved some of this interaction.  If they lore doesn't in any way reflect the dialogue we are having, then we will know you were just blowing smoke up our asses.  Do not forget that our dialogue is US giving YOU the benefit of the doubt.

First and foremost, kudos and thanks for taking your time to post here, we really appreciate it, though we deeply disagree with you. Nonetheless, please keep discussing with us lest any hope towards the Narrative team be buried deep in the oceans and the board be renamed "Art board".

> We don't view it as 'destruction,' but as a tweak to fit with new foundational rules for the world. In making those tweaks we're looking at what players have liked and disliked for what reasons and why, and all those factors enter into our discussions. Fan theories? Check. Past reworks? Check. Recent events? Double check. I absolutely agree that it was on us to tell you we'd be moving in this direction sooner, and that we dropped the ball in that regard. We are, I think, doing well to fix that.

To call a retcon a tweak is really demeaning. You kicked out of existence the core of the League of Legends setting. More explicitly, you erased from the game's story what gave the title to the game itself. It's like developing a new game of Pokemon without Pokemons or publishing the third book of the Lord of the Rings without any ring reference therein. It's something major, not a tweak.
But well, you said you wanted to separate the game from the lore, indeed, so it may make sense to you; the problem being that the game retains elements of said lore and the new Sion is now not an Arnie impersonator anymore because of this and all his VO it's all about immersion. So it's a bit confusing, either you develop the story for the game or you do it separately. If one includes the other, you can't possibly argue the retcon is "a tweak". It's a retcon. There's a reason there exists a separate word for it, because retcons and tweaks are not the same thing.
 
> Again, have to be careful here. Do we reveal everything and never surprise you at all, or constantly surprise you and have less interaction? That's the tightrope we're walking. I agree that a 'shock reveal' is unpleasant, but remember that our goal isn't simply to turn everything on its head - we want to shock and delight positively, when at all possible.

A personal opinion: surprises are good when it's about brand new content, something which didn't exist before. Retcons and reworks as undebatable surprises? Bad, bad idea. A writer is free to continue his/her story the way she/he wants when publishing a sequel, but I think you'll agree that publishing a sequel which states in the preface that past events are no more or different, leaving many plot holes while doing so, well, is nearly impossible. Seriously, were I an editor, I wouldn't ever publish it. That's no way to do narrative.

> The entire world is being redefined, and Bandle City is indeed among the reworks. Some of the changes you might not like, others you probably will. I personally (and be aware that I haven't had any input on Bandle city) *hate* the mothership. Someone else might love it. But we're not going to throw out **or** keep anything based on a small handful of opinions - we keep what makes for the most interesting and vibrant stories, while considering what every side has to say. I hope we can be more transparent of that going forward.

How do you know it's a handful of opinions? Another Rioter stated you're not driven by surveys in response to a question. If you do no surveys, you have no statistics to back it up. If you don't discuss with the community prior to decisions being made (like with the IoW), how can you know it's just a handful?
How can you judge what *we* find *interesting and vibrant*? You already made a mistake with the IoW, judging from the boards.
So, I'll repeat the question: do you have surveys and statistics to back all this up? I'd accept it if you told me that you have objective good reasons (as in: we've got data) for having done so. But as it is, you've done all based on your judgment of what we might like and didn't correct yourself when the boards replied that we didn't actually like it.

Guessing at what we'd like is good for new content, not for the rework of the already released content.

> Again, have to be careful here. Do we reveal everything and never surprise you at all, or constantly surprise you and have less interaction? That's the tightrope we're walking. I agree that a 'shock reveal' is unpleasant, but remember that our goal isn't simply to turn everything on its head - we want to shock and delight positively, when at all possible.
> 


Yes. There's no point in surprises when they are badly transparent as Sivir's story in the Shurima event.  I would much rather see interaction on the boards. Sion's relaunch was miles better, yet even then we learned NOTHING about *Sion* other than he's an undead weapon currently aimed by Swain. I enjoyed LeBlanc's and even Vlad's appearances in it for what that's worth. 

"Blah blah blah website soon(tm)" Still waiting for what IMO should have been the baseline for the relaunch of lore project. 

Sadly I feel like not being able to say who's working on what, just means a representative of Narrative has to continue to 'face tank' the forum goers who are unhappy for the whole team. I suppose that's completely your call but at the same time, we don't get to praise those whose work we enjoy other than in a generic 'good job narrative' way. This feels backward to me versus even work-for-hire on company owned characters works in other industries. This is the opposite of TRANSPARENT, IMO.

> If you were any other company I suppose I could empathize but let's be frank for a moment. In the past few years have any of your surprise reveals, in the realm of lore, actually worked? I can think of one. Sion. That's it. Freljord didn't go over well. The Retcon has not gone over well. Shurima has not gone over well. Character and item revamps have done better but have also been problematic. I'd advise erring on the side of caution. Shocking and delighting positively has not been your forte and is something that companies who have very positive relationships with their fan bases have to do carefully. Even the recent surprise character lore revamps have irked people. This tactic is *not* your strong suit. You guys do fine when you're introducing skins or a new game mode. Maybe just refrain from it until you build up some good mojo and then reintroduce it and work at it.

This is a really good point!

> Someone else might love it. But we're not going to throw out **or** keep anything based on a small handful of opinions

So, if the majority of the lore community that actually participates in the boards disagreed with the decision to remove the institute, it's still counted as a "Handful of opinions"? If we're counting the entire community of LoL, then yeah, we're a minority, but we're also the only people who've actually read the lore, everyone else I know who plays doesn't care at all about the lore. 

They really don't, I'm not going to bring up "Muh E-sports" but still, they weren't interested because the original premise was weird, they weren't interested because it just didn't have much else, and the stuff that was already set-up, just disappeared. I showed people I know the JoJ (Rammus X Cactus OTP) on the wiki (It's the only place I could find it anymore), but since it was a wiki, they didn't want to read it. The lore indifference is born from the inability to find it, not that the old story wasn't cool, or funny, or interesting, it's just that almost no one can get to it.

Even people I know who like lore don't care about League's lore, the new stuff doesn't interest them at all. They go to Dawngate because of the way they're doing it, they have an actual say in the story, not rampant fanon appeasement but they're given two possible choices from the current storyline, and then you vote, with matches being played for the votes, it makes you more invested in the story than, "Here, the lore is this now because we thought it was a cool idea." also the web comic doesn't hurt.

I'm also seriously wondering why the lore team is now you guys, if you apparently hated the original stuff? I'm not trying to be mean, I seriously want to know this. 

But seriously in the end, we're realistically the only opinion you're going to get on any of this, and don't count surveys, it's not good for the demographics for an online game, especially one where you have rampant smurfing, and bot accounts. You're only ever going to get a handful of opinions on this.

> Yes, story progression. Champs doing things that progress forward on a linear timeline. With the in-client tech issues we (sadly) could not showcase this, but with the website we can.

That sounds needlessly complicated, to be honest.

Let's say you're writing a new story where Ashe, Tryndamere, Udyr, Braum and Gragas are traveling to Bandle City to negotiate some sort of trade deal with Teemo, Tristana, Lulu and Corki and Veigar comes in to do his little bit of fun.  You now have 10 champion stories you'd have to update and make kosher with each other.

Frankly, given how Singed's bio hasn't been fixed in over two years, I have my doubts this can be done at all, much less to the standards we should expect from Riot.

Also, are we going to get these new stories in the same "experimental" format some of the more recent champs have received?  Will that Freljord grandmother tell the legendary story of the great Braum meeting that one guy with the technological hammer/cannon from Piltover?

Honestly, I'd rather have the champ bios remain high quality stand alone stories and tell these extra tales in a separate format.

> Frankly, given how Singed's bio hasn't been fixed in over two years, I have my doubts this can be done at all, much less to the standards we should expect from Riot.

Thank you
I've been screaming this for two years.

You know, you can fix Singed's bio without pulling a full Trundle or Xerath.  In fact, if you need that "pure bastard" character in the overall lore, you couldn't do much better than Singed.

I had something in mind like this for him:
